pageProps.contentHtml:
inverse function theorem, Schwarz lemma

Let f ⁣:D→C\func{f}{\D}{\C}f:D→C be an injective and holomorphic function with f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0 and f′(0)=1f'\p{0} = 1f′(0)=1. Show that then

inf⁡ {∣w∣∣w∉f(D)}≤1\inf\,\set{\abs{w} \mid w \notin f\p{\D}} \leq 1inf{∣w∣∣w∈/f(D)}≤1

with equality if and only if f(z)=zf\p{z} = zf(z)=z for all z∈Dz \in \Dz∈D.
Solution.

Suppose inf⁡ {∣w∣∣w∉f(D)}=1+ε>1\inf\,\set{\abs{w} \mid w \notin f\p{\D}} = 1 + \epsilon > 1inf{∣w∣∣w∈/f(D)}=1+ε>1 for some ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. Equivalently, f(D)c⊆{∣w∣≥1+ε}f\p{\D}^\comp \subseteq \set{\abs{w} \geq 1 + \epsilon}f(D)c⊆{∣w∣≥1+ε} so taking complements, f(D)⊇{∣w∣<1+ε}=B(0,1+ε)f\p{\D} \supseteq \set{\abs{w} < 1 + \epsilon} = B\p{0, 1 + \epsilon}f(D)⊇{∣w∣<1+ε}=B(0,1+ε).

Let U=f−1(B(0,1+ε))⊆DU = f^{-1}\p{B\p{0, 1 + \epsilon}} \subseteq \DU=f−1(B(0,1+ε))⊆D, which is open since fff is continuous. Because fff is injective, fff restricts to a biholomorphism g−1=f∣U ⁣:U→B(0,1+ε)g^{-1} = \func{\res{f}{U}}{U}{B\p{0, 1 + \epsilon}}g−1=f∣U​:U→B(0,1+ε), so g ⁣:B(0,1+ε)→D\func{g}{B\p{0, 1 + \epsilon}}{\D}g:B(0,1+ε)→D with g(0)=0g\p{0} = 0g(0)=0. Applying the Schwarz lemma to g((1+ε)z)g\p{\p{1 + \epsilon}z}g((1+ε)z), we get ∣g(z)∣≤∣z∣1+ε\abs{g\p{z}} \leq \frac{\abs{z}}{1 + \epsilon}∣g(z)∣≤1+ε∣z∣​ for z∈B(0,1+ε)z \in B\p{0, 1 + \epsilon}z∈B(0,1+ε). Thus, for z∈Uz \in Uz∈U, f(z)∈B(0,1+ε)f\p{z} \in B\p{0, 1 + \epsilon}f(z)∈B(0,1+ε) and so we may apply the inequality:

∣z∣=∣(g∘f)(z)∣≤∣f(z)∣1+ε  ⟹  ∣f(z)∣≥(1+ε)∣z∣.\abs{z} = \abs{\p{g \circ f}\p{z}} \leq \frac{\abs{f\p{z}}}{1 + \epsilon} \implies \abs{f\p{z}} \geq \p{1 + \epsilon}\abs{z}.∣z∣=∣(g∘f)(z)∣≤1+ε∣f(z)∣​⟹∣f(z)∣≥(1+ε)∣z∣.

But 0∈U0 \in U0∈U, so for zzz close enough to 000,

1+ε≤∣f(z)z∣→z→0∣f′(0)∣=1,1 + \epsilon \leq \abs{\frac{f\p{z}}{z}} \xrightarrow{z\to0} \abs{f'\p{0}} = 1,1+ε≤∣∣​zf(z)​∣∣​z→0​∣f′(0)∣=1,

a contradiction. Thus, inf⁡ {∣w∣∣w∉f(D)}≤1\inf\,\set{\abs{w} \mid w \notin f\p{\D}} \leq 1inf{∣w∣∣w∈/f(D)}≤1 to begin with.

To prove the second claim, first, if f(z)=zf\p{z} = zf(z)=z, then f(D)=Df\p{\D} = \Df(D)=D, so d(f(D)c,0)=1d\p{f\p{\D}^\comp, 0} = 1d(f(D)c,0)=1 and we have equality. Conversely, suppose we had equality, which means

f(D)c⊆{∣w∣≥1}  ⟹  f(D)⊇{∣w∣<1}=Df\p{\D}^\comp \subseteq \set{\abs{w} \geq 1} \implies f\p{\D} \supseteq \set{\abs{w} < 1} = \Df(D)c⊆{∣w∣≥1}⟹f(D)⊇{∣w∣<1}=D

As before, let U=f−1(D)U = f^{-1}\p{\D}U=f−1(D) and let g ⁣:D→U⊆D\func{g}{\D}{U \subseteq \D}g:D→U⊆D be the holomorphic inverse of fff restricted to UUU.

1=(f∘g)′(0)=f′(g(0))g′(0)=f′(0)g′(0)=g′(0),1 = \p{f \circ g}'\p{0} = f'\p{g\p{0}}g'\p{0} = f'\p{0}g'\p{0} = g'\p{0},1=(f∘g)′(0)=f′(g(0))g′(0)=f′(0)g′(0)=g′(0),

so by the Schwarz lemma, g(z)=zg\p{z} = zg(z)=z and so f(z)=zf\p{z} = zf(z)=z as well, which completes the proof.
